topic.title: NZ Republic vs. NZ Democracy
topic.body:
**[Facts]** 
Simply put - the key difference between a democracy and a republic lies in the limits placed on government by the law, which has implications for minority rights. Both forms of government tend to use a representational system â€” i.e., citizens vote to elect politicians to represent their interests and form the government. 
 
**In a republic, a constitution or charter of rights protects certain inalienable rights that cannot be taken away by the government, even if it has been elected by a majority of voters**. 
 
**In a "pure democracy," the majority is not restrained in this way and can impose its will on the minority.**
 
Most modern nations are democratic republics with a constitution, which can be amended by a popularly elected government. This comparison therefore contrasts the form of government in most countries today with a theoretical construct of a "pure democracy", mainly to highlight the features of a republic.
 
**[Opinion]**
The New Zealand Republican Party would guarantee the following constitutional rights:
- A no-strings-attached, weekly Universal Basic Income of $300 paid to every New Zealand Citizen or Permanent Resident.
- The right to the personal use of recreational substances without legal consequences (drug decriminalisation).
- The right to free speech, and the right to have one's voice heard on online platforms.
- The protection of private property.
- The abolition of most forms of copyright law.
- The abolition of punitive and unnecessary taxes i.e. Tobacco tax, plastic bag tax, fuel tax, imports tariffs, etc.
- The introduction of higher taxes on wealthy individuals and corporations, while reducing taxes for low earners.
- The right to online privacy.
- More to come.
